stem: A 36-week pregnant client with severe preeclampsia is being monitored on a magnesium sulfate infusion. Based on the documentation, which finding is most predictive of an impending eclamptic seizure?

options.text: Presence of 4 beats of ankle clonus and 4+ reflexes

rationale.correct: The presence of 4 beats of ankle clonus and 4+ reflexes (a1) is the most predictive finding of an impending eclamptic seizure. While hypertension and proteinuria are components of preeclampsia, hyperreflexia (4+) and ankle clonus (involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions) indicate extreme central nervous system (CNS) irritability, the final stage before a seizure (eclampsia). The headache and scotoma (seeing spots) further support cerebral edema.
clinicalPearls: Therapeutic magnesium range: 4–8 mg/dL. Levels less than 4 mg/dL are ineffective; levels greater than 8 mg/dL are toxic.

If reflexes are 0 (absent) or respiratory rate is less than 12, the client is experiencing magnesium toxicity. If reflexes are 4+ and clonus is present, the client is at risk of seizure despite the magnesium infusion.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting the magnesium level (a2) because it is 'on the chart.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize physical findings over therapeutic lab values. A therapeutic lab value does not guarantee the client will not seize if their CNS is exhibiting 4+ clonus.

exhibits.title: Neuromuscular Assessment
exhibits.content:
Admission: Reflexes 2+ (Normal).
Current: Patellar reflexes 4+ (Hyperreflexive). Presence of 4 beats of ankle clonus noted during dorsiflexion of the foot. Client reports seeing 'spots' (scotoma) and having a severe 'frontal headache' that doesn't go away.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & Labs
exhibits.content:
Vitals: BP 172/112. HR 88. RR 14. Temp 98.6°F.
Magnesium Level: 6.2 mg/dL (Therapeutic range 4–8 mg/dL).
Urine Protein: 3+ on dipstick.
